entry.title: Day 1 Gradients
entry.content:
Ok, so I’m pretty familiar with how to make a button:

<button style="background: #cfcfcf;">Hi there!</button>

Preview:

Ok, but that’s plain boring. Let’s add some juicy gradient goodness to the mix!

Gradient backgrounds

Gradients are most often used with the background CSS property, and there are two types:

  • Linear Gradient
  • Radial Gradient (I’ll cover this later)

Linear gradient is the popular kid on the block, and it’s defined like so:

background: linear-gradient(direction, color-stop1, color-stop2, ...);

Ok, let’s try that on our button:

<button style="background: linear-gradient(to bottom, red, blue);">Hi there!</button>

Ah, that’s looking better.

I mean, sorta. It still looks horrendous (when you consider the actual colors). I think having subtle gradients would work better, I found a website that showcases some good looking gradients here.

Let’s take one example … OrangeFun:

<button style="
  background: linear-gradient(to bottom, #fc4a1a, #f7b733);">Hi there!</button>

Oh, that looks sweet — but why? What’s the right amount of “distance” between colors so it turns out OK? I plugged the two colors into Photoshop to see how they differed:

Hmm, it seems that the primary difference is in that H value (“Hue”), with a difference of about ~30°. Nice. That’s probably a good benchmark to consider when picking colors for a gradient combo.

Lesson: Vary Hue (up to 30°) to get a good color combo for a gradient.

Finally, let’s add abit more CSS to make the thing look nice and polished:

<button style="
  background: linear-gradient(to bottom right, #f7b733, #fc4a1a);
  border: 1px solid #f7b733;
  border-radius: 3px;
  color: #fff;
  padding: 10px 20px;">Hi there!</button>

Ah, that looks lovely! Giving it a bit of breathing space (using padding) and a border with the darker of the two shades looks great.

When using a gradient, use the darker shade as the border

Also, I changed the direction of the gradient so it looks like the light is coming from the top left. I remember reading something about that somewhere, and will make tomorrow’s post about diving into lighting and shadows and all that goodness!

Stay tuned.

Next…

  • Radial gradients
  • Lighting, shadows
entry.summary: Today, I practice gradients and try to figure out what makes a good gradient from an unsightly one!

entry.title: Hello
entry.content:
Hello there! My name’s Yazin, and I’m a developer. I’ve always wanted to get better at designing things, but could never really get around to it.

So here’s my attempt at doing that — in baby steps!

Everyday, I’ll plan to spend about 15 to 30 minutes learning a new lesson in design. Alot of this will, naturally, be about CSS!

I know a few things, but this’ll help me practice — and hopefully, reach an adequate level before too long.

Let’s get started!
